column1: Jessica Poon, a LA-based animation director from Hong Kong, will
column2: speak at Riverside City College on&nbsp
column3: Tuesday, November 11 at 3 pm in the Digital Library Auditorium. The event is free and is open to the public.

column1: Poon recently graduated from California Institute of the Arts’ Character Animation program. Her student film, Origin, was nominated by Annie Awards, which is the Oscar in animation, for Best Student Film of 2012. Her films have also screened in International film and animation festivals including, Zagreb Animafest, International Short Film Festival Oberhausen and ASIFA Student Animation Festival.
Her work concerns humanity and interpersonal relationships as well as political and environmental issues, as well as geometries.
The RCC Art Club and Associated Students of RCC are sponsors of the event. Contact Will Kim at will.kim@rcc.edu for more information.?

column2: line-height:1.5em'>Husband and wife, Henry Tarlow and Serita Stevens, will be the featured guests at the Riverside City College Inside Hollywood Speaker Series on Wednesday, November 12, at 6 pm in the Digital Library Auditorium. The event is free and open to the public
column3: however, guests must be at least 12 years of age.

column1: Stevens, an award-winning author and producer, has written several bestselling books including

column2: and the prequel of the TV series&nbsp

column1: Cagney and Lacey. She has written and developed such scripts as
Lilac Dreams. Currently she is working on two nonfiction crime books,
The Heist, a story of a notorious art heist as told by one of the perpetrators
Discovery of Evidence, a true story about a mother who was falsely accused of the murder of her 6-year-old son and her own attempted suicide. Her latest fiction,
Against Her Will, is a young adult novel about a teenager wrongly thrown into a psychiatric hospital and her struggles to survive.
Stevens, who is originally from Chicago, holds a master's degree in communications and writing and has over 40 years of teaching experience at UCLA and USC. She just released a book -&nbsp
The Ultimate Writer's Workbook for Books and Scripts
column2: – which is available at Amazon, Barnes &amp
column3: Noble, and her website, www.seritastevens.com. She is also a sought-after judge, recently heading the panel that selected the winner of the&nbsp

column2: trailer contest. Stevens will do a book signing at the close of the event. &nbsp
column3: Books will be available for purchase.

column1: Meanwhile, Tarlow is a retired nurse who married Stevens in 2006. He has seen work in several commercials (as a Viking in What’s in Your Wallet? ads) and music videos as well as movies and web series. Currently, he is a featured extra in the new HBO pilot,&nbsp
Westworld, staring Ed Harris and Anthony Hopkins.
In addition to their on- and off-screen successes, the two are partners in a production company, Pupperazzi Productions.&nbsp
For information regarding the Inside Hollywood Speaker Series, contact Susan St. Peters at susan.stpeters@rcc.edu or&nbsp
(951) 222-8269.

Performance Riverside will go from blonde to green as Shrek the Musical takes over the Landis Auditorium at Riverside City College. Coming off a successful run of Legally Blonde, Performance Riverside will present Shrek the Musical over two weekends, beginning November 7.

Based on the Oscar-winning DreamWorks Animation film, Shrek The Musical is a TONY Award-winning fairy-tale adventure featuring new songs from Jeanine Tesori (Thoroughly Modern Millie, Caroline or Change) and a sidesplitting book by David Lindsay-Abaire. Everyone's favorite ogre brings his beloved friends to life on stage, proving there's more to the story than meets the ears.

This musical tells the tale of an unlikely hero who finds himself on a life-changing journey alongside a wisecracking donkey and a feisty princess who resists rescue. Throw in a short tempered bad guy, a cookie with an attitude and over a dozen other fairy tale misfits, and you’ve got the kind of mess that calls for a real hero. Luckily, there's one on hand and his name is Shrek.&nbsp
The performance presents a trove of creative opportunities including costumes, sets, and puppets (there is a fire-breathing dragon after all).&nbsp
“This musical is one the whole family should see together,” said Jodi Julian, associate professor of Theater Arts.

column2: Performing Arts production, it’s directed by Gary Krinke and choreographed by Renee Liskey and stars Stephanie Renne Wall as Fiona, Josh Tangerman as Shrek, Charles Allen McCoy as Donkey and Johnny Fletcher as Lord Farquuad. For tickets and show time information, call the Landis Box Office at

column1: ?Animation Instructor Work to be Part of the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Lima, Peru

column7: Riverside City College animation instructor Will Kim has been busy outside the classroom.

column6: Kim recently completed work on two projects. One, Symphony of the Soil, has received the New York Times Critic’s Pick and the other, Amazon Gold, will be shown as part of the United Nations’ climate change conference (Framework Convention) in Lima, Peru in December. The film covers the global warming effects on the Amazon, and has aired on PBS as part of its series on The Price of Gold: Illegal Gold Mining in the Amazon.
Kim hired his own animation team for both projects. He didn’t have to look far, reaching out to former RCC students Roseanne Tan, Andrew Aviles, Seyha In, and Leon Lam.&nbsp

“The fact that I was given complete artistic freedom in terms of the style of animation, animation techniques/mediums (watercolor in these particular cases), and character/environment design made both projects a great opportunity,” Kim said. “This sort of freedom is rare when you work for feature films, but I think I got lucky because I met the directors (Ruben Aaronson: Amazon Gold and Deborah Koons Garcia: Symphony of the Soil). They respected my art and animation and trusted my decision makings in creating animation and scenes.”
Amazon Gold, narrated by Academy Award winners Sissy Spacek and Herbie
column7: Hancock, is a disturbing account of a clandestine journey into the Amazon rainforest. War journalists Ron Haviv and Donovan Webster, led by a Peruvian biologist, uncover the savage unraveling of the pristine rainforest. They bear witness to the apocalyptic ecological destruction caused by illegal gold mining. An animated rodent (Agouti) springs to life to tell the story of his ecosystem. Amazon Gold reaffirms the right of the rainforest to exist as a repository of priceless biodiversity.

column6: Symphony of the Soil is a 104-minute documentary film that explores the complexity and mystery of soil. The film examines the complex relationships between soil, water, atmosphere, plants and animals. It also explores our human relationship with soil, the effects of agriculture, deforestation and development, and the latest scientific research into soil’s role in sustaining a livable environment. Filmed on four continents and featuring renowned scientists and working farmers and ranchers, Symphony of the Soil highlights possibilities of healthy soil leading to a healthier planet. By understanding the elaborate relationships and mutuality between soil, water, the atmosphere, plants and animals, we come to appreciate the complex and dynamic nature of this precious resource.?

column1: Riverside City College’s Career and Technical Education (CTE) department will hold an event – Non-traditional Employment for Women (NEW) - on October 17 at 9 am, encouraging young women to consider careers in CTE fields. RCC expects 250 local high school students from five local high schools to attend the NEW career-exploration event.

According to a national study in March 2013 conducted by the Institute for Women’s Policy Research and Wider Opportunities for Women under the auspices of the National Coalition of Women and Girls in Education and the National Coalition on Women, Jobs and Job Training, women are sorely underrepresented in CTE fields. Fewer than one in six students nationally are studying in fields such as architecture and construction-related CTE programs, and fewer than one in 10 students in transportation, distribution and logistics are women. Conversely, women comprise 80 percent of students enrolled in human services CTE programs, which lead to lower-paying positions.

“This event will expose young women to occupations that normally they wouldn’t consider or have possibly never heard of,” said Patricia Avila, the College’s director of CTE programs. “Many of these programs are underrepresented by women traditionally, so our goal is to dispel the myth that women are not suited for these career paths. We hope this event will generate interest among the girls.”

??Riverside City College (RCC) and Norco College (NC) will receive over $2.7 million from the Trade Adjustment Assistance Community College and Career Training grant, which is co-administered by the U.S. Department of Labor and U.S. Department of Education. A total of 270 community colleges won $450 million under the job-driving initiative. In California, a consortium of colleges earned $14.9 million.

The monies will allow colleges and universities in California to partner with employers in the region, expanding and improving education and career-training programs in order to help jobseekers obtain skills needed for today’s in-demand jobs in industries like information technology, health care, energy, and advanced manufacturing.
RCC will receive over $1.1 million over the next three years

“This grant will provide us with the funding needed to strengthen and initiate new areas,” said Patricia Avila, dean of instruction, Career and Technical Education (CTE). “Specifically, the two areas of focus will be cyber security and quality assurance. The funding will allow the College to update curriculum in cyber-security. It will also allow the hiring of adjunct faculty to teach new curriculum in quality assurance, operations and production management and quality systems. In essence, it will allow RCC to create a program in coordination with cyber security.”
At NC, the College has earmarked the money for training in advanced manufacturing and supply chain technology occupations.
“After two years of planning with our consortium partners, this award is an exciting tipping point for Norco College to enhance our training programs and develop Earn &
column2: Learn programs with regional employers,” said Kevin Fleming, dean of instruction, CTE Programs &amp
column3: Grants. “This grant award will enable Norco College to help residents attain high-wage, high-skilled employment within our local communities.”

column1: Chaffey College will distribute the grant money to the Inland Empire Regional Training Consortium (IERTC), which will use the funds to create the STEM Education Business Incubator Center at facilities provided by California Steel Industries in Fontana, CA. The Center will develop a curriculum and award certificates in the field of advanced manufacturing applications. The consortium of colleges is composed of Chaffey
column12: and the University of California, Riverside.

column1: The consortium has partnered with the Inland Empire Manufacturers’ Council, which has a membership of over 50 manufacturers, including local employers such as California Steel Industries, Brithinee Electric, Cott Beverages, Steelscape, Ashley Furniture, California Quality Plastics, Nestle Waters North America, and Southern California Edison to develop this program.?
